column5: Methodologic approaches to evaluating new highly sensitive diagnostic tests: avoiding overdiagnosis
column37: More sensitive diagnostic tests can contribute to overdiagnosis; evaluate via test–treatment trials

column49: The development of ever-more-sensitive diagnostic technologies that challenge existing disease definitions is a major contributor to the rising problem of overdiagnosis and subsequent overtreatment. We should evaluate new diagnostic tests not through regular methods of assessing diagnostic accuracy but by evaluating disease outcomes through test–treatment trials, argue de Groot and colleagues. column5: Finding the right balance between precision medicine and personalized care
column37: Despite impressive advances in omics-based medicine, person-centred care remains important.
column39: personalized medicine, precision medicine, clinical assessment, evidence-based medicine
column49: Although they are often conflated by some commentators, precision medicine and personalized care are not synonymous.  Personalized care is the careful tailoring of investigations and therapies to individual patients based on evidence, consideration of circumstances and clinical skill and has long been the hallmark of good clinical care.  Precision Medicine relies on increasingly detailed molecular characterization of disease states using the biologic omics platforms (genomics, proteomics, metabolomics, etc) to better individualize diagnostics, prognostics, and therapeutics based on each patient's unique genetic and physiologic characteristics.  While there have been impressive advances in precision medicine in the past decade (particularly in the field of oncology), the potential impacts of precision medicine may be overestimated.  Better population health requires advances not only in omics-based medicine, but also in traditional elements of personalized care.

column5: Evaluating the effects of Quebec’s public-private drug insurance system
column12: Doesn't need to go in print
column37: The province’s public-private system has increased employer and household drug expenditures
column39: Drug costs, Quebec, Health Canada
column49: Since 1997, Quebec’s mixed private-public system of drug coverage has had mixed policy results. Under the system, all eligible workers in Quebec are required to have private insurance for prescription drug costs and all other residents are required to purchase drug coverage from the provincial government. The system increased access to insurance for previously uninsured working-age populations. It thereby increased access to medicines for working-age residents of Quebec. However, access to medicines in Quebec is still lower than in comparable high-income countries with universal systems of health and pharmaceutical coverage. Quebec’s private-public system of drug insurance brought with it new and steadily increasing deductibles, co-insurance rates, and premiums. These charges had negative consequences on access to medicine among beneficiaries of Quebec’s formerly more-comprehensive public plans: most notably among Quebecers aged 65 and older. The premiums, deductibles, and co-insurance under private and public drug plans in Quebec represent a greater proportion of income for lower-income households than for high-income ones. This makes the regime a regressive means of financing prescription drug costs in the province. Despite hopes to the contrary, Quebec’s regime increased taxpayer-financed drug expenditures and significantly increased employer- and household-financed expenditures. If pharmaceutical costs in Quebec had grown at the same rate as they did in the rest of Canada rate since 1997, Quebecers would be spending $1.7 billion less per year on prescription drugs than they do today. If costs in Quebec had fallen to levels observed in countries with universal, single-payer drug coverage systems, Quebecers would be saving billions more each year.

column5: Addressing overestimation of the prevalence of depression based on self-report screening questionnaires
column37: Studies that use screening instruments to identify cases may estimate depression burden too high.
column39: Mental health, psychiatry, screening questionnaires, depression
column48:
For Twitter, please use #mcgillu and #mcgillmediau hashtags. The twiiter handles for my hospital and McGill are @CIUSSS_COMTL and @McGillMed. 
For Facebook, please use CIUSSSCentreOuest.
column49:
Because of depression’s high burden, it is crucial to accurately estimate prevalence. Conducting diagnostic interviews to properly classify depression, however, is expensive. Thus, researchers increasingly rely upon self-report screening questionnaires, which are completed independently by research participants, to estimate depression prevalence in different groups, such as among patients with a particular medical disease. Our analysis found that most recent publications on depression prevalence used screening questionnaires rather than diagnostic interviews.
Screening questionnaires, however, are not designed to definitively determine whether depression is present. Rather, they are designed to cast a wide net and identify a large pool of people who may have depression, so that healthcare professionals can follow-up. Our analysis demonstrated that when researchers take the shortcut of using screening questionnaires, instead of diagnostic interviews, to estimate depression prevalence, prevalence is substantially exaggerated. In one example, depression prevalence from 183 studies of medical students was 27% based on screening questionnaires, but only 9% based on a diagnostic interview, similar to the rate of young adults in the general population.
Our analysis also demonstrated that screening questionnaires exaggerate prevalence most when true prevalence is low. Prevalence is exaggerated by 2-3 times when true prevalence is under 10%, but only very minimally when true prevalence is high (e.g., over 20%). Thus, screening questionnaires blur distinctions between low- and high-prevalence groups.
Researchers must use diagnostic interviews to accurately estimate prevalence. A two -stage estimation method that combines screening questionnaires and diagnostic interviews can reduce resource requirements and generate valid prevalence estimates.

column49: Studies of the human genome and microbiome provide strong evidence for evolutionary medicine. Evolutionary medicine’s classification of disease causation provides a unifying framework. An expanding range of medical disciplines is using the principles of evolutionary medicine and data from genomics to guide the practice of medicine. All areas of medicine are likely to soon adopt this approach to practice. This view of medicine provides a compelling framework for life long learning.

column5: Type 2 diabetes in a 4-year-old child
column37: Type 2 diabetes must be considered in a child with risk factors, despite age and lack of symptoms
column39: diabetes, pediatrics
column49: Type 2 diabetes in children is becoming more common around the world. Although it is typically diagnosed in adolescence, an increasing number of children under age 10 years are being diagnosed. In 2016, a child was diagnosed at the age of 4 years at the Diabetes Education Resource for Children and Adolescents in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. This child did not present to medical care due to the classic diabetes symptoms but rather he was tested for diabetes because he had a number of known risk factors for developing type 2 diabetes including being overweight, of a high-risk ethnic background, born to a mother with diabetes and having a family history of diabetes. This child was of Oji-Cree heritage which is a population that may be affected by a change in DNA that lowers the body’s ability to secrete insulin. He was initially managed with lifestyle changes but a decline in his blood sugar control made insulin management necessary. This report shows the importance of testing for diabetes in children before puberty (< 10 years old) even if they are asymptomatic when they have multiple risk factors for diabetes. These children require treatment as without proper care and follow up the loss of blood sugar control happens quickly putting them at risk of early and late complications of diabetes.

column5: Congenitally transmitted Chagas disease in Canada: a family cluster
column37: It’s estimated that thousands of people with undetected and untreated Chagas disease are living in Canada
column39: Immigrants, Latin America, Chagas disease
column48:
Facebook: @CUSM.MUHC
Twitter: @cusm_muhc
Linked-In and Instagram: muhc
You can also tag @McGillU and @McgillMed
column49: Chagas disease (CD), caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, is endemic in Latin America.  Primarily transmitted via the bite of triatomine insect vectors, in Canada the parasite can only spread via congenital transmission and infected blood transfusions or organ transplantation.  This report describes two Canadian-born siblings with asymptomatic indeterminate CD who were most likely congenitally infected and whose infections were incidentally uncovered.  This familial cluster of CD highlights the possibility of vertical transmission in Canada.  Blood donor screening will continue to uncover new cases of chronic CD.  All immigrants from Latin American countries with higher CD endemicity should be offered testing for CD.  Early treatment can prevent serious long term sequelae.  It is expected that Canadian physicians will increasingly uncover patients with CD and should therefore be informed about CD management. Our unexpected findings should allow all offspring (including adult children) of known CD-positive mothers to be screened for CD.

column5: The need for health in all policies in Canada
column12: linked commentary
column37: Governments should analyze all its decisions in light of social determinants of health and favour policies that promote health
column39: health policy, government of canada, social determinants of health
column49:
Health promotion is the domain of social, economic and environmental ministries, whereas medical ministries treat illness more than they prevent it.  As a result, the WHO is encouraging governments to embrace the concept of Health in All Policies.  This concept illuminates that increased medical spending is not unambiguously good for population health when social spending does not keep pace. So physicians should anticipate that containment of future compensation increases and/or closure of tax advantages for doctors will promote population health by preserving funds for government agencies that focus on income, child care, housing, transit, the environment, etc.

Healthy social spending should prioritize fair levels of investment for young and old alike.  Governments must be mindful of the risks to health promotion for younger generations that follow from policy decisions to grow spending on medical care and retirement income for the aging population without collecting sufficient revenue to pay for those increases.  

A commitment to health in all policies also invites analysis of public decisions that shape major costs of living, like housing prices that have left behind the incomes of many people.  In such cases, health in all policies does not require more spending, so much as it requires changes to the housing market via zoning policies that permit more suitable supply, and/or tax policies that discourage harmful demand.  The latter is consistent with the health in all policies logic that governments should collect revenue by taxing more what harms health (like home prices decoupled from earnings) while taxing less what promotes it (like higher earnings for the typical citizen).

column5: Human Granulocytic Anaplasmosis acquired  from a Blacklegged Tick in Ontario
column37: A man developed fever, headache and vomiting after a tick bite in Ontario —but it was not Lyme disease.
column39: Lyme disease, antibiotics, fever, headache, inflammation, ticks; prostate cancer, leuprorelin
column49:
This report describes the case of a 79-year old man in Southeastern Ontario who presented
to hospital with five days of fevers, headache, nausea and vomiting. Two weeks earlier
while in the forest near his home, he found a tick attached to his skin. Blood tests showed
that he had low platelets and white blood cells. Testing was performed which confirmed a
diagnosis of human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA). This is an infection acquired from
ticks infected with the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum. He was treated with two
weeks of the oral antibiotic doxycycline and recovered well.
This report documents an account of HGA acquired within Ontario. The first report of HGA
in humans was in 1994 and the first published report in Canada was in 2009. Populations
of ticks may be migrating North in recent years, changing the spread of infections like HGA.
The tick that spreads Anaplasama phagocytophilum also spreads Borrelia burgdorferi, the
bacterium that causes Lyme disease. The clinical presentation of the two diseases shares
similarities, so it can be challenging to discern the two. Typically, with Lyme disease there
is a bulls-eye like rash at the site of the tick bite, and most basic blood work is usually
normal. With HGA, rash is less common, and laboratory abnormalities like low platelets and
low white blood cell count are more common.
To further study and understand the spread of HGA, it may be useful for provincial public
health agencies to record cases of the emerging disease.

column5: Apraxia
column12: 5 Dec: Department changed from "Poem" to "Encounter" per instruction from BJS
column37: A meditation on failure as a physician and father.
column39: Alzheimer disease, dementia, poetry
column49:
This piece is based on several encounters I have had with patients in whom I have diagnosed young onset Alzheimer’s disease in middle life. This clinical experience is juxtaposed to a particular domestic encounter with my own little boy, which had striking resonance for me due to my encounter with the father of a young family in clinic earlier that day. The piece meditates on the several ways I regularly fail to help – as a doctor and as a father – but also, the intense fragility of shared time and the possibility of tiny ‘buildings’ against despair. 

The title ‘Apraxia’ references several senses of impaired action – my patient’s and my own, as a doctor and father.

column5: Repeated influenza vaccination for preventing severe and fatal influenza infection in older adults: a multicentre case–control study
column12: MBS had wanted this published during the flu season; To SE2 Dec. 7; 170910-syn to SE1 Jan. 16; to SE2(KP) Jan. 19; to PR Jan. 19; F'd Jan. 19
column36: Repeated influenza vaccination and influenza severity
column37: Influenza hospitalizations and disease severity were reduced in older adults repeatedly vaccinated for influenza.
column39: Influenza, vaccination, older adults
column49:
Although elderly people may accumulate many doses of vaccine over the seasons, the effect of repeated influenza vaccination for preventing severe cases remains unclear. When influenza vaccination fails to prevent influenza illness, vaccination may still have an additional effect by reducing influenza severity. 
We carried out a multicentre case-control study in elderly patients hospitalized during two influenza seasons in Spain. Severe hospitalized influenza cases were defined as patients who required intensive care unit (ICU) admission or who died. We evaluated the effect of the influenza vaccine of the current and three previous seasons on preventing influenza hospitalizations and reducing influenza severity. 
Repeated influenza vaccination showed a protective effect of 31% in preventing non-severe influenza hospitalizations, 74% in preventing ICU admissions, and 70% in preventing mortality. Among hospitalized patients with influenza, repeated vaccination reduced the risk of severe outcomes by 55%.
Repeated influenza vaccination was highly effective in preventing severe influenza in the elderly. This high effect may be explained by the combination of influenza hospitalizations prevented and the reduced severity of hospitalized influenza patients in whom vaccination did not prevent influenza illness. Since severe cases may be prevented by these two mechanisms, the vaccine effect against severe influenza may be greater than against mild cases and the benefit of influenza vaccination may be greater than that estimated in previous studies. The prevention of severe influenza was mainly observed in patients repeatedly vaccinated in both the current and previous seasons, which reinforces the recommendation of annual influenza vaccination in the elderly.

column5: Brown tumours of the spine presenting with acute urine incontinence
column12: Back to DK for cuts to text Aug. 15. FromAU Aug. 16; back to AU Aug. 16 to get changes in pdf highlighted
column37: Neurologic deficits caused by spinal brown tumours may be the first evidence of hyperparathyroidism.
column39: brown tumours, spine, orthopedic surgery, hypophosphatemia, hypercalcemia, emergency medicine, endocrinology
column49: A 29-year-old man attended the emergency department with a five day history urinary incontinence which began acutely. His muscle power in both lower limbs was symmetrically decreased (from 5 to 4-) with numbness. On investigation, he had hypercalcemia (13.94 mg/dl, normal range [NR]: 7.9-9.9 mg/dl) and hypophosphatemia (1.8 mg/dl, NR: 2.4-4.7 mg/dl) with elevated I-PTH (1956 pg/ml, NR: 14-72 pg/mL). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of spine showed two lesions over posterior elements of T10 and L4, respectively and the T10 lesion compressed the spinal cord . He had an urgent surgical decompression of the T10 lesion which, on histology, was composed of round to spindled mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with some bony trabeculae. His neurologic deficits recovered two weeks after the operation. Because of pain in his left forearm he had an x-ray which also showed suspected brown tumors. Parathyroid scan (Tc-99m Sestamibi) and ultrasound suggested a right parathyroid adenoma which was confirmed on parathyroidectomy. Multiple spine brown tumors are rare compared to those found in the extremities, clavicle, ribs and pelvis. Neurologic deﬁcits caused by spinal brown tumors may be the ﬁrst symptoms of undiagnosed hyperparathyroidism. Brown tumours are often lytic, but can also be solid or mixed with fluid content. In patients presenting with lytic or solid spine lesions with fluid component, brown tumors should be included in the differential diagnosis together with a search for evidence of primary, secondary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

column5: Laryngeal stridor in rheumatoid arthritis
column37: Cricoarytenoid joint involvement in rheumatoid arthritis can cause stridor, dysphonia and cough
column39: Rheumatoid arthritis, polyarthritis, Indigenous people,
column49: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) affects about 300,000 Canadians and 1% of the general population. RA classically causes inflammation, pain and progressive destruction of small joints in hands and feet. Although uncommon, it can also cause arthritis in the cricoarytenoid joints (CAJ) in the larynx which control the movement of vocal cords. Early signs of CAJ arthritis include hoarse voice, difficulty or pain in swallowing, cough and shortness of breath with progression to late complications such as stridor. This case described a rare late complication of CAJ arthritis with not only immobilization of vocal cord but also a large fluid-filled inflammatory synovial pouch, together leading to upper airway obstruction. Prompt recognition of early signs of CAJ arthritis as a manifestation of RA by physicians can prevent life threatening late complications.

column5: A case of SGLT-2 inhibitor related euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis
column49: SGLT-2 inhibitor is a relatively new class of anti-diabetic medication approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2013 for treatment of type 2 diabetes. SGLT-2 inhibitor blocks glucose reabsorption in the kidney, which leads to loss of glucose in the urine. Increasing number of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis cases have been reported in patients taking this drug. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) usually presents with elevated blood glucose level. However, many patients with DKA while on an SGLT-2 inhibitor presented with near-normal glucose values, which potentially delayed the recognition and treatment of DKA. Risk factors include intercurrent illnesses, surgery, decreased carbohydrate intake, dehydration, insulin deficiency, excessive alcohol intake and latent autoimmune diabetes in adults. Patients should be counseled regarding the risk factors and symptoms of DKA, and if feeling unwell, they should check for urine or serum ketones, even if blood sugar is relatively low (≤14 mmol/L). If ketones are present, SGLT-2 inhibitor should be withheld, hydration needs to be maintained and insulin supplementation has to be adjusted. When the DKA has resolved and the precipitant has been removed, the SGLT-2 may be restarted. If no other cause for DKA was identified, patients should not restart treatment with any SGLT-2 inhibitors to avoid recurrences of ketosis. However, the decision to restart any SGLT-2 inhibitor after an episode of DKA still remains controversial.

column5: Abdominal wall varices: The sign of chronic Budd-Chiari syndrome
column37: Budd–Chiari syndrome can present with dilated, tortuous superficial veins on the anterior abdominal wall.
column39: Venous disease, cardiovascular medicine, abdominal varices
column48: Facebook account id: bhupinder singh with e mail id: doc_bhupi@rediffmail.com
column49: We described a case of 49-year-old male who presented with abdominal wall varices and was further evaluated and diagnosed to have chronic Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) due to membranous obstruction of inferior-vena cava. He underwent endovascular management with placement of self expandable stent.BCS occurs secondary to in-situ vascular thrombosis, extrinsic compression by adjacent tumor or its invasion, and idiopathic membranous obstruction. The membranous or the short segment obstruction of the IVC is the common variety in Asia. In western country thrombotic obstruction is the common cause. The typical triad of BCS is abdominal pain, hepatomegaly and ascites. The clinical presentation of BCS depends on the extent and rapidity of the hepatic-vein occlusion. Doppler ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice. Other investigatory modalities include contrast-enhanced computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging. The mode of management varies according to the extent of disease and anatomical variety of BCS. Medical therapy consists of diuretic therapy to control ascites and anticoagulation therapy for prevention of thrombus extension. The relief of venous outflow obstruction can be done with techniques like percutaneous thrombolysis, venous angioplasty with or without stenting, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt and surgical shunts. Liver transplantation may be needed in rare instances.

column5: An emergency response to the opioid overdose crisis in Canada: a regulated opioid distribution program
column12: DK asked for changes at pre-dummy; 19 Dec: to AU to ask for ref; rec'd Dec. 19 and revised.
column37: A scaled pharmaceutical-grade opioid distribution program could stop overdose deaths now
column39: Opioids, pharmaceuticals, pain, addiction, public health
column49: The opioid overdose crisis in Canada is only getting worse.  An estimated 2,458 overdose deaths were recorded in 2016 and the numbers could easily double in 2017.  The crisis has exposed serious gaps in the drug treatment system and harm reduction programming across Canada.  While people using opioids have been accessing their drugs through illegal channels for decades, it is only in the past few years that the illegal drug supply has become increasingly dominated by potent synthetic opioids – mainly fentanyl.  Making the situation worse is a renewed interest in reducing opioid prescribing that has further squeezed the street supply.  People who have been using opioids for many years are suddenly in grave danger of being poisoned by a single lethal purchase.  While naloxone distribution, harm reduction programs, and expanded access to drug treatment are critical in the response to the overdose crisis, they will have a limited impact as long as people are driven to purchase drugs that are unpredictable and potentially lethal. The pragmatic approach to the current crisis is to introduce a regulated program that provides access to safer and reliable opioids.  A program to supply injectable heroin and/or hydromorphone to a small number of chronic opioid users has been proven to be highly successful in Vancouver. Unfortunately it is completely impractical to scale up an injectable hydromorphone program that would reach the thousands of people who are at imminent risk of overdose. An untested but compelling argument could be made for a large scale-up of hydromorphone pills that are cheap and readily available.  Initiating a rapid scale up of an opioid distribution program would require some regulatory changes, a monitoring and evaluation strategy, along with a general shift in how we are approaching the opioid overdose epidemic.  At this point our options are very limited.

column5: Placenta percreta
column37: Previous cesarean delivery is a risk factor for placental invasion of the myometrium
column39: Cesarean section, neonatal medicine, pediatrics
column49:
Cesarean sections are often required for the safe delivery of a neonate or for a mother’s well-being. Considered a very safe procedure, one rare but serious consequence is having the placenta in a future pregnancy implant over the scar and then invade into the uterus. This condition is called placenta accreta and it occurs in approximately 1 out of 1000 deliveries. The most severe form of this condition is called placenta percreta, where the placenta invades through the uterus and into the abdominal cavity or surrounding organs. 

We present a case of a woman who required a classical Cesarean section for the delivery of a pre-term neonate. A classical Cesarean section differs from a regular Cesarean in that an incision is made higher on the body of the uterus through the thick muscular wall. This is often the only way to deliver very pre-term neonates as there is not enough room on the uterus to make a usual horizontal incision. When the woman in our case had her next pregnancy, the placenta invaded through the prior Cesarean section scar which was placed high on the uterus. This was a very unusual complication and required a specific surgical plan in order to ensure a safe delivery for both the mother and her baby. 

When placenta percreta occurs, the safest treatment is to deliver the neonate shortly before term by Cesarean section. Immediately afterwards, the uterus is removed, called a hysterectomy. This prevents life threatening bleeding to the mother because the placenta cannot be detached once it has invaded deeply into the uterus.

column5: Assessing the safety and immunogenicity of recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus Ebola vaccine in healthy adults: a randomized clinical trial
column12: 170074-syn - to SE1 April 4. Published ahead of linked commentary 170704 -- bring together in print
column14: commentary commissioned from Frank Plummer - due 29 May
column36: Safety of new Ebola virus vaccine: an RCT
column37: Trial shows safety and immunogenicity of new Ebola virus vaccine
column39: vaccines, public health
column49: The Canadian Ebola vaccine, known as VSV-EBOV, is an experimental vaccine still being evaluated in humans. It was developed by scientists at the National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg, Canada. This vaccine does not contain Ebola virus; it consists of a genetically engineered and weakened vesicular stomatitis virus (an animal virus) that expresses a surface protein from the Ebola virus, and thereby stimulates an immune response targeted against Ebola virus when introduced into the body. Other clinical trials have tested this vaccine in healthy humans, but this is the first one to monitor volunteers and collect samples out to six months following administration of the vaccine thereby providing some new information around its long-term benefits, safety, and side effects. Three doses of VSV-EBOV were assessed in this study; none of the doses elicited any safety concerns, and side effects were generally mild to moderate. Recipients of all three doses showed a significant immune response when compared to a comparator group that did not receive the vaccine, with immune responses remaining high through to the six months assessments. This study is important in demonstrating that the vaccine is safe and effective in healthy adults and shows that the levels and length of protection offer promise that it will be beneficial in immunocompromised individuals and can very well be expanded for use in Ebola disease endemic areas in the near future.

column5: Oral morphine versus ibuprofen administered at home for postoperative orthopedic pain in children: a randomized controlled trial
column37: Morphine no better than ibuprofen for managing postsurgical orthopedic pain at home
column39: morphine, ibuprofen, acetaminophen, orthopedic surgery, children
column49: Ambulatory surgery is becoming increasingly common in children, thus placing the responsibility of post-operative pain management largely in the hands of caregivers at home. However, it is well described that post-operative pain management in children is suboptimal. Barriers include a lack of evidence guiding therapy and growing concerns surrounding opioid prescription practices. Given the advisories surrounding the use of codeine in children, oral morphine and other opioids are being increasingly prescribed. However, evidence guiding therapy is limited and studies have cited significant safety concerns. Our study is the first to explore the effectiveness of oral morphine for post-operative pain following ambulatory surgery in children. In children age 5-17 years who underwent minor ambulatory orthopedic surgery, we found that oral morphine was not superior to ibuprofen in relieving pain for the first 48 hours following discharge. Both agents produced a clinically significant decrease in pain but oral morphine was associated with significantly more side effects, most commonly drowsiness. This suggests ibuprofen, the safer analgesic choice, should be the first line option in children for mild to moderate post-operative pain at home. More than 90% of children experienced pain significant enough to require analgesia, underscoring the importance of adequate pain management, even following minor surgery.

column5: Autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation for systemic sclerosis – a challenge for the Canadian health care system
column37: Provincial funding model is a barrier to providing new effective treatment for this uncommon disease.
column39: systemic sclerosis, scleroderma, stem cell transplants, hematology, rheumatology
column49: Systemic sclerosis is a rare rheumatologic disease associated with poor quality of life and high death rate. Both the quality of life can be improved and the death rate decreased using a new treatment, so called autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation (autoHCT). AutoHCT has been used for decades for patients with certain cancers, particularly lymphoma. Only recently, autoHCT has been shown to be beneficial also for patients with systemic sclerosis. AutoHCT is usually performed in cancer centers. The first challenge for the Canadian health care system is that cancer centers may be reluctant to care for patients with systemic sclerosis without additional funding to ensure adequate care for these patients. The second challenge for the Canadian health care system is the provincial funding model. Most provinces have their own transplant programs, and residents of each province are expected to receive transplants in their own province. However, for rare diseases like systemic sclerosis, only a few teams are needed that would maintain skills and expertise, eg, one in Western and one in Eastern Canada. Inter-provincial agreements need to be created that would allow patients from a province that does not have an experienced team to receive the treatment in a province that has such a team.

column5: Influences on the start, selection and duration of treatment with antibiotics in long-term care facilities
column37: Prescriber tendencies influence the nature of antibiotic drug use in Ontario's long-term care facilities.
column39: antibiotics, long-term care, senior care, physician prescribing patterns
column49: Antibiotics are among the most common medications prescribed to long term care (nursing home) residents.  Many of these prescriptions are inappropriate, and expose patients to avoidable risks of allergy, side effects, Clostridium difficile infection and antibiotic resistant bacteria.  In this Ontario-wide study of nearly 1700 doctors prescribing  to more than 93,000 long term care residents, we found that antibiotic prescription decisions were driven more by who was prescribing the antibiotic than by who was receiving it.  The decision to start an antibiotic, the choice of which antibiotic to use, and the length of the prescription were all subject to prescriber habit.  A prescriber’s historical antibiotic prescribing behaviour was a strong predictor of their current antibiotic decision-making, even after accounting for the characteristics of the patients they were treating, including age, gender, comorbid  illnesses, functional status and indwelling devices.  Extreme high outlier prescribers tended to remain extreme high or high outliers the next year.  Since antibiotic prescribers seem to have individual tendencies towards antibiotic initiation, selection of specific drugs, and use of prolonged treatment duration, audit-and-feedback to prescribers may be a promising tool to improve antibiotic use in long-term care.

column5: Association of delay of urgent or emergency surgery with mortality anduse of  health care resources: a propensity score–matched observational cohort study
column37: Mortality and health resource use were higher when urgent or emergency surgery was delayed
column39: noncardiac surgery, emergency surgery, surgical wait times, hip fracture, steroids, insulin, piperacillin–tazobactam, meropenem
column49:
Patients who wait longer to have certain emergency surgeries, especially hip fracture surgery, are thought to have an increased risk of bad outcomes after surgery. Whether the relationship between longer wait times and bad outcomes for emergency surgery patients applies to all types of emergency surgery (excluding cardiac surgery) is not known. 
At the Ottawa Hospital, a new and more detailed system to grade the urgency of surgery and to set acceptable wait times for surgeries was implemented. Following implementation of this system, we studied whether patients who did not have their emergency surgery within an acceptable wait time were more likely to die after surgery, stayed longer in hospital, or cost more to care for after surgery.
After taking into account differences between patients who had surgery ‘on time’ compared to patients who had their surgery delayed, we found that patients who didn’t have their emergency surgery within the acceptable wait time were more likely to die after surgery, stayed longer in hospital and were more expensive to care for. Furthermore, most documented reasons for patients not having surgery on time were related to a lack of available operating rooms, doctors and nurses. We estimate that for every 60 patients who have delayed emergency surgery, one would die because of delay. Current data suggests that about 20% of patients wait too long for emergency surgery. This could translate into over 400 deaths in Canada every year being caused by delayed emergency surgery.

column5: Perinatal suicide In Ontario, Canada: a 15-year population-based study
column37: In Ontario, 1 in 19 maternal deaths was attributable to suicide, with most occurring late in the first postpartum year
column39: pregnancy, postpartum care, suicide, psychiatric care, anxiety disorder, psychotic disorder, mood disorder
column49: Death by suicide during pregnancy and postpartum has not been well studied Canada.  To help us understand how to prevent suicide, we linked population-based health administrative data with coroner death records (1994-2008) in Ontario, Canada to examine how often women die by suicide during pregnancy and in the 1st year after delivery, and what kinds of health services these women used prior to suicide. The suicide rate in pregnancy and postpartum was 2.58 per 100,000 live births. Suicide accounted for approximately 5% of deaths among pregnant and postpartum women. The most common time for suicide to occur was in the final quarter of the first postpartum year although deaths by suicide occurred throughout pregnancy and postpartum. The highest suicide rates were in rural and remote regions of the Province. Perinatal women were most likely to die from hanging (33%) or jumping/falling (20%); this differed from women who died by suicide non-perinatally where overdose was the most common cause of death. Only 39% of pregnant or postpartum women who died by suicide had contact with a mental health professional in the 30 days prior to suicide, although 40% had contact with an obstetrician, and 65% with a pediatric provider for their child. The suicide rate among pregnant and postpartum women is comparable to international estimates; death by suicide accounts for 1 in 20 deaths among pregnant or postpartum Canadian women.  Non-mental health care providers may be in an important position to actively assess for risk and direct women to appropriate interventions.

column37: For children with newly diagnosed diabetes, having a usual provider of care decreased ketoacidosis risk
column39: diabetes, diabetic ketoacidosis, primary care
column49:
Key Points:
• A delay in the diagnosis and initiation of treatment of type 1 diabetes in children may result in the development of diabetic ketoacidosis, an avoidable and life-threatening complication at first time diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
• Having a usual provider of primary care is important in improving health outcomes for children; however primary care access is an important problem in Canada
• Evidence supports that having access to a usual provider of primary care appears to be important in decreasing the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis at diabetes diagnosis 
• This provides further evidence on the need for initiatives that promote primary care access for children

column5: Consolidated principles for screening based on a systematic review and consensus process
column12: flagged for commentary
column37: After nearly 50 years of use, 10 commonly used principles to guide population screening have been updated.
column39: screening & diagnostic tests
column49:
• Screening decisions, whether made at clinical or population levels, are complex and require consideration of many factors.
• Fifty years ago, Wilson and Jungner published “Principles and practice of screening for disease”, a seminal document that highlighted ten principles that should be considered when making a screening decision.  
• Although the Wilson and Jungner principles are remarkably enduring, many attempts to modify or create new screening principles have been made over the ensuing five decades.
• We analyzed the Wilson and Jungner principles along with 40 sets of principles (including 367 unique principles) that we identified (through systematic review and a consensus process with international screening experts), which ultimately led to the establishment of 12 consolidated principles for screening
• These 12 consolidated principles maintain focus on disease/condition principles (e.g., relative importance and burden of the disease/condition; who should be targeted for screening) and test/intervention principles (e.g., characteristics of screening ‘tests’; interpretation of screening test results; who should be targeted for different types of post-screening intervention), but provide more emphasis on program/system principles (e.g., characteristics of screening ‘programs’; economic evaluation; performance management).
• An implication of this shift in emphasis is that a broader range of evidence is relevant and a broader range of experts and stakeholders can help to inform the assessment and integration of a broader evidence base to inform screening guidelines for clinicians and screening programs for population health leaders.  
• These 12 consolidated principles represent a comprehensive and iterative modernization of guidance to inform population-based screening decisions.

column5: We need a "made in Canada" orphan drug framework
column37: Access to safe and affordable therapies for patients with rare diseases must be better supported
column39: Rare diseases, orphan drugs, drug regulation, drugs
column49:
Orphan drugs are used to treat rare diseases which collectively, are estimated to affect 1 in 12 Canadians.  Regulatory frameworks for orphan drugs have been created in more than 25 countries over the past 30 years.  Canada remains one of the few developed countries without such a regulatory framework.  
     Canadians with rare neuromuscular diseases including spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) and Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) have witnessed a dramatic increase in clinical trials and, for the first time, approval of disease-modifying therapies.  The emergence of these novel therapies has emphasized the need for a Canadian orphan drug framework. 
     Canadian patients with rare diseases require timely access to safe and effective treatments.   Canada must explore novel incentives and invest in our country’s existing strengths.  Since provincial health care budgets are allocating a growing proportion of their expenditure toward pharmaceutical costs, a national strategy is needed to balance short-term accessibility with long-term financial sustainability.  As such, Canadian incentives for drug development and regulatory approval must extend beyond tax credits and the reward of high prices.  A ‘made in Canada’ orphan drug strategy could ensure that the government engages early in the drug development process.   By investing in existing Canadian infrastructure during the ‘infancy’ of a given drug’s development, governments could position themselves to negotiate potential price-caps or price reductions.  
     Canada’s orphan drug framework must involve consultation with patients and families with rare diseases, clinicians, clinician-investigators and industry representatives.  As physicians who care for children with rare diseases, we call upon the Government of Canada to fulfill its’ 2012 commitment and develop a ‘made in Canada’ orphan drug framework to improve patients’ access to emerging therapies.

column5: The Role and Impact of Cost-Sharing Mechanisms for Prescription Drug Coverage
column37: Copayments are based on drugs’ official prices not the actual confidential prices paid by insurers

column49:
Implementing co-pays only to cover the price over freely available cost-effective reference products might be the best way to use cost-sharing mechanisms in a way that minimizes the number of patients not filling their prescriptions, increases cost-effectiveness, and offers patient choice.
In a more plain language: 
In order to minimize the number of patients not filling their prescriptions and offer patient choice, cost-effective reference products should be free. Patients should pay out-of-pocket only for the price difference when they choose more expensive products with no medical justification.

column5: Delivering primary health care in Canada's North
column36: Primary health care in northern Canada
column37: We need to move beyond practitioner-delivered services to embrace a more comprehensive model
column39: First Nations people, northern health care
column49: Residents of remote communities in Canada’s northern territories do not have the same access to health care as Canadians living in urban centres. With a large number of widely scattered small communities, health care cannot rely on physicians, whether resident or visiting. First-contact care is provided by nurses, a system that has existed for decades and it ensures round-the-clock access in the community. Technological innovations, appropriate training, better coordination and communication, and adoption of culturally based healing systems and environmentally sustainable communities can potentially improve the quality of care. However, we need to adopt a comprehensive concept of concept of “primary health care” that  is well aligned with indigenous values and concepts of wellness. Health professionals need to ally with indigenous leadership and patient (ie. community) representatives to develop and implement primary care reform to redress inequalities between North and South, and within the North, between indigenous and non-indigenous people.

column5: Narrowing the treatment gap in the management of opioid use disorder
column36: Treatment gap in opioid use disorder
column37: Primary care health care providers are essential to narrow the treatment gap for opioid use disorder.
column39: opioids, addiction medicine, pain treatment
column49: North America is in the midst of a public health crisis related to opioid use disorder and overdose.  Against this backdrop, the Canadian Research Initiative in Substance Misuse (CRISM) has published an evidence-based guideline on the management of opioid use disorder. This timely publication offers succinct guidance for physicians regarding the pharmacologic management of patients with opioid use disorder. At a time when a minority people who need treatment for opioid use disorder receive it, the current Canadian guideline moves the narrative in the correct direction by clearly stating that it is intended for all frontline providers, “with or without specialized experience in addiction treatment.” It is these frontline providers who are vitally important to decrease the existing treatment gap. The messaging is clear regarding several key elements. First, pharmacotherapy is unequivocally the evidence-based first-line treatment for opioid use disorder. Second, withdrawal management alone should be avoided and is associated with relapse, morbidity, and death. Finally, psychosocial interventions should not be viewed as a mandatory component of treatment.  The critical next steps, at a national and international level, are to increase provider education regarding recognition and management of opioid use disorder and chronic pain; to reduce stigma associated with substance use disorders; to decrease provider barriers to prescribing opioid agonist treatment; to improve medication prescription coverage and increase access to care; to expand access to harm reduction modalities; and to encourage ongoing research into best practices for the prevention and treatment of opioid use disorder.

It is time for a second opinion on physician retirement to consider what can be done to meet the needs of women in medicine, physicians in rural areas, and whether it is time for a public pensions system for physicians. Furthermore, it is time to address practical issues relevant to physician retirement including mechanisms that accommodate those who would benefit from scaled-down or flexible work hours.

column5: The Decision to Screen for Disease: Can we Improve Upon Wilson and Jungner’s Principles?
column37: Updated principles highlight the importance of postimplementation evaluation of screening programs.
column39: screening & diagnostic tests
column49: For the past 50 years, Wilson and Jungner’s 10 criteria that need to be met before introducing population-based screening has been the benchmark for assessing the appropriateness of launching a screening program. Over this period, a variety of screening programs have met these criteria and contributed to significant reductions in adverse outcomes through early detection and treatment. Yet, until now, there have been few efforts to evolve and refine Wilson and Jungner’s 10 principles, and to go beyond the key conditions necessary to consider screening to the key elements necessary to ensure that a screening program is successful. Dobrow and colleagues sought to assess whether attempts had been made to update Wilson and Jungner’s criteria in the period since they were published, gather that literature, and ask experts in the field to critique these updates, consolidate, and refine them. The original 10 criteria are now 12 consolidated principles that address these criteria, but also the conditions that must be in place for screening to be successfully implemented and maintained at the population level. The update also includes attention to patient autonomy, and also being sensitive to the needs of individuals to be fully informed about what to expect from screening.  Th refined criteria are an important contribution, insofar as it reaffirms the important criteria that must be met to initiate screening, but also the criteria that must be met to ensure that programs are high performing. A review of these criteria reveals that much work remains to be done for many screening programs to achieve their fullest potential.

column5: Warning of an increased risk of vertebral fracture after stopping denosumab
column12: KP: This would also be good to publish sooner rather than later.
column37: Warn patients of an increased risk of vertebral fracture and prescribe an alternative agent.
column39: Denosumab, bisphosphonates, osteoporosis, women's health, adverse reactions, patient safety
column49: Denosumab (ProliaTM) is a well-tolerated, injectable medication proven to reduce the risk of fractures in older women with osteoporosis. Recent evidence reveals a small but serious risk of developing new spine fractures after stopping this drug. This article describes the medical information that led to denosumab being approved in Canada in 2010 and reassuring 10 year drug safety while on medication. Canadian physicians are prescribing this medication in increasing numbers, but patients may be stopping denosumab after a few doses or not taking the drug on the recommended schedule every six months.  Initial reports showed that patients had a fall in the bone density they had gained, once the drug was stopped. Recent case reports and follow-up of patients from a large study of denosumab in older women with osteoporosis revealed a small but increased risk for rapidly developing new, often multiple, spine fractures in patients who stopped taking denosumab. This occurred as soon as 8 months following the last injection. Bone researchers and specialists have called for physicians and patients to be made aware of the potential risk of multiple “rebound” fractures when denosumab is stopped. When prescribing denosumab, physicians should consider the patient’s ability to take the medication regularly. Patients should not stop denosumab without seeing their doctor. Patients already taking denosumab who are considering stopping therapy should see their physicians to discuss the merits of either replacing it with another osteoporosis medication or continuing denosumab treatment until there is more information about how best to go off it safely.

column5: The need for national leadership to develop a pan-Canadian approach to ethics review in Canada
column12: Three pages; KP says this doesn't need to go in print. (kb)
column37: National leadership is needed to harmonize processes and facilitate multicentre, multiprovince studies.
column39: research ethics approval, research ethics boards,  human research participants
column49: Obtaining research ethics approval is an important part of health research conducted with human subjects. Increasingly, researchers undertake multicentre studies, which can require them to seek approvals from a number of research ethics boards (REBs). Many researchers have complained about variability in decisions made by REBs, long time delays, and costs associated with obtaining ethics approval. Attempts have been made to reduce variation and delays but no national framework covering all types of health research exists. In this absence, provincial initiatives have been set up, but obtaining ethical review for the conduct of national and international multicentre studies remains difficult. In order to truly harmonise ethics review in Canada, national leadership is required to drive change that is both evidence-based and responsive to criticisms of ethics review.

column37: A challenge to the constitutionality of the Genetic Non-Discrimination Act runs counter to its positive impact.
column39: Genetic testing and discrimination, Canadian and Quebec governments, Huntington disease
column49: The Genetic Non-discrimination Act is critical for advancing Canadians’ health and genomics research in Canada. Yet, the Quebec government is challenging the constitutionality of the act. The act has already had a positive impact; it is thus imperative that it remains intact.

column5: Community paramedicine is growing in impact and potential
column12: linked to Agarwal research
column37: Paramedics are increasingly delivering sustainable and high-quality preventive health care in communities.
column39: Older adults, community paramedicine programs, CP@clinic, social housing, geriatric medicine
column49: Community paramedicine began as a grassroots movement among paramedics who recognized a need for new services that emphasized a more proactive and preventative approach to care, using paramedics in expanded roles. Several research studies have found that community paramedicine programs are effective in improving health outcomes for some populations, can reduce use of emergency services and may lower costs to the health care system.

column5: Expanding treatment for hepatitis C infection in Canada
column37: Current guidelines support all patients with HCV receiving curative therapy regardless of fibrosis level

column5: Hearing between Wor(l)ds: Rhetorical Space and Disrupting Narratives in Medicine
column37: Something was missing in the spaces between the words that left me unsettled as I listened to Nico
column39: Mental health, vulnerable populations, refugee, sexual orientation, trauma
column49: In this essay, the author considers some of the challenges and limitations of the use of narratives in medical practice and medical education. Rather than the conventional focus on the details of the story itself, or the interaction between storyteller and listener, Dr. Berkhout argues that greater attention needs to be paid to what can be understood as the “rhetorical space” that surrounds narrative in medicine: the power differentials, and the social, political, and historical context that a story emerges from. Linking this to feminist and queer scholarship in narrative studies, Berkhout suggests that this could make for better listening and better medicine.

column5: Better data to drive more effective care for people with latent tuberculosis infection in Canada
column37: Data on people with latent tuberculosis infection are insufficient, which impedes our ability to find and treat those most at risk.
column39: tuberculosis, public health
column49: Canada lacks a systematic approach to LTBI control making  the current LTBI processes ill-equipped to identify and prioritize people most at risk for reactivation of TB. Better data are needed to monitor and act on trends and to support a more equitable and fair use of resources.

Morris and Gollish discuss the relative efficacy of postoperative antimicrobial prophylaxis and antibiotic-impregnated bone cement to prevent surgical-site infection. (sub reqd) [KEYPOINTS] Tues 11am

column49: Maternal and child health (MDGs 4 and 5) rely on interaction among families, health systems and policies within a framework of stable political, economic, social, technological and environmental factors, say Kissoon and colleagues. Despite gains made over the past 15 years, we've a long way to go. (sub reqd) [WEB IMAGE]  Wed 9am

(sub reqd) [KEYPOINTS] Wed 9am

column39: medical error
column49: About 10%–15% of adults have a hard time telling left from right. In industries like aviation and health care, this can lead to devastating consequences. Gormley and Brydges discuss the importance of researching both the effect of right–left discrimination problems on clinical error and possible treatment. (sub reqd) [KEY POINTS} Thurs 10am

column5: Race and preterm birth rates in North America
column36: Race and preterm birth in Canada v. US
column37: Black women in Canada and the US have a similarly increased risk of delivering a preterm infant
column39: pregnancy, obstetrics
column49: A new study has found that, although preterm birth rates are lower in Canada for women of both black and white race, black women in Canada and the US have a similarly increased risk of delivering a preterm infant. What remains a mystery is whether this phenomenon has its origins in the social, educational, occupational and economic circumstances that women face before and during their pregnancies, or whether it is underpinned by some inherent difference. (sub reqd) Tues 9am

column49: Fewer than 6 out of 1000 Canadians living with class II or III obesity undergo bariatric surgery each year, and there are substantial disparities in access across the country. Bariatric surgery should be integrated into a comprehensive national obesity management strategy, says Sharma. (sub reqd) [KEYPOINTS] Wed 12pm

column5: Preparing for the arrival of "pink Viagra": strengthening Canadian direct-to-consumer information regulations

column39: Erectile dysfunction, sexual medicine, hypoactive sexual desire disorder, viagra, cialis, flibanserin, tadalafil
column49: Valeant Canada is likely to apply for approval of their newly acquired drug, flibanserin, and to embark on a campaign highlighting the "common problem" of female sexual desire dysfunction. Unlike direct-to-consumer advertising, such information campaigns are allowed in Canada. The federal government must ensure that Health Canada has the time and resources to protect the public from so-called informational messages that are essentially another form of drug advertising. (sub reqd) [KEY POINTS] Tues 9am

column12: epaginated
column37: Sustainable development goals aim to build on millenium goals and recognize global interconnectedness
column39: None
column49: The sustainable development goals (SDGs) adopted at the UN summit last fall will guide global development and global health from 2015 to 2030. They comprise goals and targets to address five areas: people, planet, prosperity, peace and partnership. They recognize the interconnectedness of countries and disciplines, and as far as health is concerned, they aim to build on the gains of the “millenium development goals” adopted in 2000. The authors explain how. (subscription required) [KEY POINTS, WEB IMAGE] Wed 12pm

column49: Commentary: Travel abroad to obtain transplant organs through commercial transactions presents considerable risks to both donors and recipients. column49: Incidentally discovered lesions of the pituitary are an increasingly prevalent health concern. This is primarily due to an increase in the use of high resolution head imaging in clinical practice, for an expanded array of indications. The differential diagnosis, optimal initial evaluation, and follow-up of these pituitary masses remains challenging. We present a case of a pituitary lesion found serendipitously on imaging, as a means of discussing the clinical implications and management of these lesions.

column5: Chronic nasal congestion and hyposmia in a 22-year-old female
column37: A 22-year-old woman has a six-month history of daily bilateral nasal congestion and rhinorrhea
column39: allergy, nasal congestion
column49:
Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is an inflammatory process of unknown etiology that affects the nose and paranasal sinuses lasting greater than eight weeks. With a prevalence of 5% in Canada CRS is a very common but sometimes poorly recognized disease. The clinical recognition of CRS can be a challenge due to the overlap of some its symptoms with other diseases, including allergic rhinitis, as the symptom spectrum for patients with CRS include nasal congestion, facial pain and pressure, nasal obstruction, nasal discharge or rhinorrhea and a complete or diminished sense of smell. The importance of diagnosing CRS is related to its impairment patient quality of life and loss of productivity both of which are modifiable with CRS specific treatment. This emphasizes the need to correctly identify patients with CRS and to institute appropriate management to optimize CRS symptom control. 

The case of a 22-year-old patient with a diminished sense of smell and nasal congestion for 6 months is used to present the evidence guiding the evaluation and initial management for such a patient. Guidance for the selective use of computed tomography (CT) imaging of the paranasal sinuses is provided. The mainstay of treatment for patients with CRS remains the daily use of an intranasal corticosteroid spray which is commonly supplemented with daily home saline irrigation, oral antibiotic therapy and a short course of oral corticosteroids when necessary. Although many patients can be managed with medical therapy alone some patients may require referral to an otolaryngologist for the consideration of surgical management.

column5: A 24-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding
column37: When should bleeding disorders be considered in a young woman with heavy menstrual bleeding?
column39: bleeding, hemophilia
column48: St. Michael’s Twitter handle is @StMikesHospital and mine is @sholzberg
column49:
Our case highlights how questionnaires about bleeding can help care providers make better diagnoses and how they can lead to better patient care.
We present the story of a young woman with a history of heavy menstrual periods. This is a common and challenging clinical problem – because “bleeding too much” is a very subjective symptom. We remind care providers that some women with heavy periods have a blood condition that make them more likely to bleed and that often these conditions are missed by regular blood work (including commonly used coagulation tests).  We review some of these blood conditions and suggest an easy-to-use questionnaire that makes it easier for care providers to identify patients with abnormal bleeding. The questionnaire also helps clarify which patients need specialist care.   
  Importantly, the young woman in this article had normal blood coagulation tests but she had excessive bleeding that was flagged by the questionnaire. Her answers resulted in a referral to a specialist, who was able to identify that she had a genetic condition that affected her blood’s ability to clot normally.  The doctor gave her medicine to control her bleeding and improve her day-to-day life.

column5: Treatment of venous thromboembolism in a 22-year-old woman taking an oral contraceptive pill
column37: Should oral contraception be discontinued in a woman being treated for venous thromboembolism?
column39: obstetrics, gynecology, pregnancy, thromboembolism, contraception
column48: Daniel Shafran is on Twitter at @MDShafran
column49:
A 22-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath on exertion. Computed tomographic pulmonary angiography confirms a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. She is prescribed rivaroxaban (15 mg twice daily for 21 days followed by 20 mg daily). She has taken a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP) since age 17. Her family physician sees her in clinic and considers alternative treatment options, duration of treatment, and how to reduce the risk of future thromboembolic events.
This 'Decisions' paper addresses the optimal treatment for this woman's PE, how to manage her OCP, duration of anticoagulation, screening for hypercoagulable disorders, and address concerns around potential future pregnancies.
Ultimately, direct oral anticoagulants, or DOACs, are the preferred treatment for acute VTE in patients without cancer. As long as she is anticoagulated, it is safe and preferred for her to continue taking the OCP to avoid menorrhagia and subjecting the fetus to unstudied medication. Anticoagulation should continue for a minimum 3 months; prolonged anticoagulation depends on the risk of recurrent VTE. Finally, should the patient become pregnant, she should receive VTE prophylaxis during the antepartum and for six weeks postpartum.

column37: Patients with acute chest syndrome require hospital admission for close monitoring and treatment.
column39: Sickle cell disease, acute chest syndrome, pain, emergency medicine, hematology, transfusion medicine
column48: This work has also been performed on behalf of the Canaadian Haemoglobinopathy association. Although CanHaem do not have a facebook or twitter page, it would be appreciated to mention that CanHaem do have a webpage at http://canhaem.org
column49: Hemoglobin disorder such as sickle cell disase are the most frequent genetic disorder in Canada and worldwide. The abnormal hemoglobin S leads to red blood cells deformation, vessels obstruction, and frequent episodes of pain crisis as well and many other complications. Among those, acute chest syndrome has to be recognized early as it is a leading cause for hospitalisation and mortality in children and adults with sickle cell disease. Our article« A fifteen year old with sickle cell disease, chest pain and respiratory distress » illustrates the usual clinical presentation and current treatment recommandation of care of such potentially fatal complication. It is based upon the Consensus statement on the care of patients with sickle cell disase in Canada, a pivotal document prepared and written in 2015 by Canadian expert and thorough review of the litterature, prepared on behalf of the Canadian Haemoglobinopathy Association (www.canHaem.org) which mission is to improve quality of care, research and education on hemoglobin disorder.

column5: Psoriasis localized to the glans penis
column37: Psoriasis localized to the genitals may be misdiagnosed and affect quality of life and sexual activity
column39: Dermatology, psoriasis, genital health
column49: A 37-year-old man presented with a pruritic, burning and scaly erythema on the glans penis for 7 weeks. He was treated with topical ketoconazole cream for 2 weeks without any improvement. Physical examination showed redness and fine scaling on the glans penis. Fungal cultures of scrapings from the glans were negative. Skin biopsy showed parakeratosis, Munro microabscesses, and acanthosis in the epidermis, which were consistent with psoriasis vulgaris. The patient received tacrolimus 0.1% ointment twice daily and the lesions were resolved after 3 weeks. He then applied it twice weekly, which prolonged flare-free interval for six months.Up to 63% of psoriasis patients have genital involvement. But psoriasis limited to the glans penis is rare, affecting only 2-5% of psoriasis patients. Patients may experience poor quality of life and sexual repression. They usually lack the typical presentation of psoriasis, which more often leads to misdiagnosis as other inflammatory diseases or, more importantly, sexually transmitted infections. Glans psoriasis is difficult to treat as glans skin is very thin and sensitive. The first-line topical agents for psoriasis vulgaris, such as corticosteroids and calcipotriol, are not suited to glans psoriasis due to their local side reactions. Topical tacrolimus, an immunosuppressant, is significantly effective and has good tolerability for inverse psoriasis on face, genitals, and intertriginous areas. Therefore, it may be more suited to a patient with chronic or recurrent glans psoriasis.

column5: Dermal leishmaniasis in a 25-year-old Syrian refugee
column36: Dermal leishmaniasis in a Syrian refugee
column37: Dermal leishmaniasis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of red dermal plaques in refugees
column39: Refugees, Syria, government of Canada, dermatology
column49: This report describes a striking clinical image of Leishmania in a Syrian refugee from Aleppo, who recently immigrated to Canada. The described histopathological microscopic findings provide important clinicopathological correlation for these lesions. We also highlight the efficacy of liquid nitrogen cryotherapy, which is inexpensive and readily accessible treatment, for the localized form of this skin infection.  Importantly, this short report highlights the “Five L’s” differential diagnosis for red dermal plaques on the face, which is commonly used in dermatology and is described in highly-specialized dermatology literature, but unfortunately is not at all known to physicians outside of our specialty. As highlighted in the paper, the Five L’s include lupus erythematosus/tumid lupus, lymphocytic infiltrate of Jessner, lymphoma cutis, lymphocytoma cutis, and polymorphous light eruption and in some instances leprosy, leishmania and lues (syphilis) should also be considered. Indeed, we have discovered that the “Five L’s” differential diagnosis, while being a powerful diagnostic tool, is “the best kept secret” in general medicine. We believe that knowing the “Five L’s” differential diagnosis is a powerful tool for all physicians who on routine basses observe patients’ faces during a clinic visit or a hospital stay (i.e., most practicing physicians). This tool will provide a powerful knowledge on how to approach a patient, who may have these types of indurated plaques on the face. Knowing this differential diagnoses also underscores the importance of recognizing these lesions and directing patients for further evaluation and a skin biopsy.

column5: L’anxiété de l’imposteur
column12: selected as possible content for Santé inc
column37: Un gouffre s’installe entre ce que les autres reconnaissent chez lui et la perception qu’il a de lui-même.
column39: physician health, alcoholism, mental health, medical humanities
column49: L’anxiété de l’imposteur touche souvent les personnes ayant des responsabilités élevées pour lesquelles elles se croient non compétentes. Dans le milieu médical, cette anxiété peut conduire à des dépendances qui espèrent cacher la souffrance. Olivier Aimesen, cardiologue renommé, se sentait lui-même imposteur et il a été confronté pendant des années à l’addiction à l’alcool, avec un impact majeur sur sa carrière médicale. Mais, il a su faire de son mal être, le moteur d’une recherche autant personnelle que scientifique. Ses études sur le Baclofen ont permis d’ouvrir la porte d’une conception nouvelle de l’addiction, même si dix ans plus tard les effets du Baclofen restent encore controversés. Ce texte imagé illustre son parcours et donnera envie de lire son livre Le dernier verre paru aux éditions Denoël en 2008. Son récit est inspirant autant pour les professionnels de la santé qui pourront reconnaître les risques de l’exigence de la performance qui est demandée dans les milieux de la santé, que pour les personnes ou patients souffrant d’addiction. L’alcool n’a pas de classe sociale, il est un anxiolytique inefficace pour ceux qui souffrent du sentiment de ne pas être à la hauteur.

column37: Sketching patients brought this doctor greater insight.
column39: Art & medicine, patients, doctor's personal reflections, patients' personal reflections
column49: Since his internal medicine internship at McGill’s Royal Victoria Hospital more than 30 years ago, Alan Blum, a family doctor and a professor of family medicine, has been jotting down visual impressions and snippets of dialogue from patient encounters. His sketches capture pivotal clinical moments. Writing in Literature and Medicine, Mary Winkler describes Blum as a physician who sees “events for art” in his patients—“individual personalities who act in a human drama of courage, despair, humor, pettiness, and death.” Blum worries that the displacement of paper by the electronic medical record and the diminishment of narrative in favor of checking boxes is irreversibly harming the patient-physician relationship. He uses his sketches to learn something beyond the compass of technological medicine. A simple sketch enables him to better recall a patient’s occupation, children, personality, joys, and sorrows. The stories reflect recurring themes: aging, anxiety, bereavement, obesity, joblessness, family disruption, homelessness, worries about contracting diseases, and the very fear of being a patient. The sketches remind us that the patient is more than a collection of symptoms. She or he is a person who lives in a community, exists within a family, and is replete with the scars of what has gone before in her or his life. The visual and textual vignettes in this presentation provide insights into the character of patients and how they feel about their illnesses. Blum’s reflective drawing evokes the richness of medical practice and deepens our empathic understanding of our patients.

column5: Evaluation of the patient with a pleural effusion
column37: The differential diagnosis is daunting, but an organized approach helps to ensure quick, appropriate care.
column39: Pleural effusion, respiratory disease, screening and diagnostic tests
column49: Patients who develop an excessive accumulation of fluid in the space around their lungs (pleural effusion) represent a challenge for front line health care providers. A long list of both benign and serious conditions can cause a pleural effusion, and therapeutic interventions may be required even before a diagnosis is established. But the necessary tools to conduct the investigations and alleviate symptoms are often not available in a primary care setting, and there is insufficient scientific evidence to guide decision-making in many areas. This article therefore offers a pragmatic approach to the evaluation of patients with a pleural effusion for the non-respiratory specialist physician. It focuses on the identification of patients requiring an urgent evaluation and describes the initial investigations needed to better characterize the cause of the effusion by exploring their interpretation and limitations. It also provides guidance for front line physicians on when to refer for specialist evaluation.

column5: hoarseness of unclear origin in adults
column36: Hoarseness of unclear origin in adults
column37: Patients with hoarseness of unknown origin lasting more than three months require laryngoscopy
column39: Laryngytis, cancer, hoarseness
column49:
Hoarseness is common and can have many causes, ranging from self-limiting infections to aggressive cancer. Cancers of the larynx (voice box) are the cause of hoarseness 1-2% of the time. In cases where the cause is unclear, surveys have shown that many health care providers will treat with a trial of medications targeting infection, reflux or allergy. When the cause of hoarseness is unclear, research has not shown any benefit to trials of treatment and this practice should be avoided. 
If a patient has a hoarse voice for more than three months, the patient should be referred to an Otolaryngology-Head and Neck surgeon to have their vocal cords visualized. Visualization is usually done with a small flexible scope and will help identify the cause of hoarseness. Over half of cancers of the larynx originate on the vocal cords and hoarseness is an early sign of disease. These cancers are easily seen when the vocal cords are visualized. Some patients have concerning features in their history and should be referred even more urgently. Concerning features include: a history of smoking, steadily worsening hoarseness, difficult or painful swallowing, noisy or difficult breathing, and ear pain. 
Outcomes in cancer of the larynx depend on how advanced the cancer is, and how long it takes to get diagnosed. Cancers diagnosed at an early stage have higher rates of survival, and better quality of life for survivors. Even in early cancers, delays in referral have been associated with poorer outcomes.

column5: Medication Overuse Headache

column37: Medication-overuse headache is common, disabling and underrecognized in clinical practice.
column39: Headache, analgesia, opioids, barbiturates, triptans, ergotamines, topiramate, b-blockers, amitriptyline, gabapentin
column48: Social media tags: Andrew Micieli (first author) twitter feed @medstudent_blog (5,300 followers).  Potential twitter/facebook hashtags: #migraine #headache #neurology.
column49: Initially referred to as ‘rebound headache,’ the term medication overuse headache is now the accepted term according to the International Classification of Headache Disorders 3rd edition. It is common and under recognized in clinical practice. These patients often suffer with debilitating, daily headaches while they wait for a referral to a neurologist or headache specialist, which can take months to years in Ontario. How to recognize this condition, what patient population is at greatest risk and which medications lead to medication overuse headache is very important knowledge for general practitioners. Once recognized, a useful skill set on how to treat medication overuse headache can lead to reduction in frequency and severity of headaches for patients, dramatically improving their quality of life and daily productivity. The cornerstone of treatment includes patient education, and through our piece we hope to bring awareness to this common leading to greater prevention and better patient outcomes.

column5: Retained intrauterine devices in pregnancy
column37: Current evidence supports removal of retained IUDs in pregnancy at the earliest gestational age possible
column39: Pregnancy, contraception, IUDs, medical devices, obstetrics, gynecology
column48: We have no social media tags.
column49: Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUDs) are widely used for contraception in North America. Despite their impressive efficacy rates, pregnancies do arise with an IUD in utero. Pregnancies complicated by retained IUDs are at increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, specifically early miscarriage and preterm delivery. Current evidence supports the removal of IUDs in pregnancy at the earliest gestational age possible. Evidence shows decreases in both miscarriage and preterm delivery rates following IUD removal in early pregnancy.  When the IUD strings are visible on exam, removal is undertaken in the usual fashion by grasping and pulling on the strings.  This can be performed by a patient's primary care provider. When the strings are not visible or retrievable on exam, hysteroscopic retrieval, or ultrasound-guided retrieval with grasping forceps, can be performed for IUD removal. In this circumstance, patients should be referred to a gynecologist with experience in advanced hysteroscopy, or a maternal fetal medicine specialist with expertise in ultrasound guided procedures, for the consideration of IUD removal.
