column5: Dual-stent retrieval for mechanical thrombectomy of refractory clot in acute stroke as a rescue technique
column37: Dual-stent retrieval may be effective for refractory clot in stroke, but its use is off-label.
column39: stroke, vascular surgery, innovation, stents
column49: Stroke is a major health problem worldwide and is the third most expensive health condition in the developed world. More than 80% of strokes are caused by a blockage of a brain artery, leading to lack of blood flow to parts of the brain (ischemic stroke). A person may lose the ability of to move one side of the body, the ability to speak and see normally, or a number of other symptoms. The sooner the treatment starts, the better the recovery. “Time is brain”. The proper treatment of stroke depends on finding out the type of stroke. For patients with ischemic stroke, the aim of treatment is to reopen the clogged artery as quickly as possible. The current standard treatments are intravenous clot buster medication (Alteplase) and intra-arterial removal of the clot (thrombectomy) by a stent-retriever device performed in an angio suite.  The clot buster medication (Alteplase) is injected though a vein and it acts by dissolving the clot. Intra-arterial thrombectomy is performed in the angio suite by using a catheter containing a small metallic stent (stent-retriever), which acts by capturing and removing the clot blocking the large artery. Both these treatments can be beneficial if these were given within few hours of stroke onset. However, even with the high success rates seen after standard stent-retriever mechanical thrombectomy, nearly one-third of patients are left without adequate reopening of the blocked artery. Here, we describe simultaneous application of two stent-retrievers for removal of clot after failed single stent-retriever thrombectomy.

column49:
2 options:
CanMEDS, the competency-based framework was developed in the 1990s and sprang from the Educating Future Physicians for Ontario (EFPO) project. However, little attention has been given to the relationship between EFPO and the 1986 Ontario doctors’ strike – the longest physicians’ strike in Canada. This paper revisits the strike - it’s causes and consequences - and argues that the vision of competency-based medical education was a response to the damaged reputation of Ontario physicians following the unsuccessful strike. 

Or a more concise statement if that is more appropriate:

Wonder where competency based medical education comes? In this article authors Hissan Butt and Jacalyn Duffin argue that this arose as response to the damaged reputation of Ontario physicians following the unsuccessful 1986 doctors' strike.

column37: Childhood malnutrition in residential schools is a significant factor influencing Indigenous health.

column49: This article examines the often overlooked impact that childhood hunger and malnutrition in residential schools had – and continues to have – on the health and well-being of residential school survivors and their families. In light of recent evidence demonstrating the connections between childhood hunger and chronic disease risk both in adulthood and in succeeding generations, we demonstrate the ways in which patterns of low birthweight, adult obesity, early-onset insulin resistance and diabetes observed among Indigenous peoples in Canada arises, in part at least, from the prolonged malnutrition experienced by many of the Indigenous children who attended residential schools.

column49: We have seen many changes in regional structures in Canada in recent years. While it may be easy for physicians to dismiss these changes as either irrelevant or damaging, it is unlikely that provincial and territorial governments are going to get the structure of their systems without the constructive involvement of doctors. The separation of doctors from the regional health authorities and LHINs which are responsible for the coordination and integration of care has been the fatal flaw in regionalization. Physicians need to become an accountable part of the main organizations administering health care in Canada to ensure that patients get quality, timely and responsive health services.

column5: Assisted Dying; it is not that easy
column49: I wrote this to reflect the difficulties we had as a family with our father when he lost the ability to direct his life and his death, and the difficulty I had as a doctor and son to support his wishes. I had done all I could to keep him alive, and although he wanted me to provide a pill for the end, I couldn’t do that . Although his wishes were clear, in the end we could not do more than get him into a hospice for end of life care and discontinue his medications. It raises the point that we may have firm ideas about how we want to die, but the reality of instituting such wishes is much more difficult when that person is no longer in mental control. I suggest that we use media to build a clear picture of what we want and don’t want, so that when doctors and health care providers meet us at our worst, they can access that media and see what we wanted when we were at our best. Not everyone gets an end of life diagnosis that allows one to be sentient right to the end, diseases that rob the mind cause difficulties for caregivers when determining end of life decisions.

column5: Evaluating a community paramedicine health promotion and lifestyle risk assessment program in older adults living in social housing: a cluster randomized trial
column12: tentatively scheduled; author requested publication during Paramedic Service Week (May 27 to June 2); to SE2 Apr. 25. To AU May 4 to confirm changes
column37: A paramedicine clinic in subsidized apartment buildings for older adults reduced ambulance calls.
column39: Older adults, community paramedicine programs, CP@clinic, social housing, geriatric medicine
column48: @GinaAgarwall @CPatClinic @McMasterFamMed @mcsander1Also the following hashtags: hemsparamedics, communityparamedicine, subsidizedhousing
column49: Low-income older adults (55 years and older) living in subsidized seniors apartment-buildings have poorer health. They have a higher risk of heart disease, diabetes, and falls. Because of these factors, data from paramedic services shows that they call 911 more often. Community Paramedicine at Clinic (CP@clinic) is a drop-in community-based program, created to prevent diabetes, heart disease, and falls in this population. CP@clinic is implemented by paramedics who are trained to do health assessments, health education, accurate blood pressure measurement, and refer program participants to community resources to improve their health. Information collected from CP@clinic is sent to participants’ family doctors with their consent. This program was tested in four subsidized seniors’ apartment-buildings in a large urban community in Canada. We evaluated whether the program could decrease 911 calls from older adult residents of buildings with CP@clinic compared to similar apartment-buildings. We also compared the quality of life and health practices of residents in these buildings to those without CP@clinic. The results show that fewer 911 calls came from buildings with CP@clinic.  Residents who attended CP@clinic had improved quality of life, reduced risk of diabetes and decreased blood pressure  over multiple visits. The first study to rigorously evaluate a community paramedicine program in Canada, we conclude that the CP@clinic program lowers 911 calls, improves health risk-factors, and improves quality of life of older adults living in subsidized housing buildings. With increasing numbers of seniors, a scale-up of CP@clinic in subsidized housing across Canada has great potential to substantially improve health and positively impact the Canadian health system.

column5: How placebo characteristics influence intervention effects
column48: Social Media tags:  #Placebo #nocebo #reportingguideline. Twitter: @JeremyHowick / @Tammy_Hoffmann. Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/DrJeremyHowick/. LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeremy-howick-6b138043/. Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/jeremyhowick/. Google Plus: plus.google.com/+JeremyHowick
column49: In many randomised trials, participants are given either a placebo or a ‘real’ treatment (and they usually aren’t supposed to know which is which). Then, if people who received the ‘real’ treatment improve more than the people who received the placebo, the researchers can say that the real treatment ‘works’. But all this means that placebo controls have to be a good control, and sometimes they are not. We often think of placebo controls in trials as simple, but they come in different shapes and sizes, have different ingredients, and range from fake pills and injections to fake surgery. And different placebos can have different effects on patients. For example, studies show that many placebos don’t appear similar enough to the ‘real’ treatments they are supposed to imitate. If they don’t, then participants in the trial will know they are taking a placebo, and could drop out of the trial or have lower expectations (thinking ‘I’m not going to get better because I’m just taking the placebo’). These lower expectations can lead to worse outcomes in some trials  - such as in those of drugs for treating pain or depression. In this article, we discuss these and other examples of placebo controls that are not good controls. To know whether a placebo control is a good control or not, we need to know all the components of it. Unfortunately, most trials don’t tell us these details. This means that we can’t sure how much the treatment that is being trialled actually helps or harms people. This articles shows that all of the people involved in doing trials need to fully describe the components of the placebo control being used so that we have accurate research to inform decisions about treatments.

column5: Effect of provincial spending on social services and health care on health outcomes in Canada: an observational longitudinal study
column12: FINALLY KP managed to commission a commentary. Kershaw, due in first thing on 4 January; it will be tight
column36: Effects of social spending on health
column37: Population-level health outcomes may benefit from reallocating government dollars to social spending
column39: health care spending, social services, social determinants of health, infant mortality, life expectancy,
column48: Daniel Dutton @danduttonyyc Jennifer Zwicker @jdzwicker PG Forest @pgfor Ronald Kneebone @RonKneebone The School of Public Policy @policy_school
column49: The largest portfolio expenditure for provincial governments in Canada is health care, but the amount spent on health care is consuming greater proportions of total spending over time and cannot continue to grow at current rates. Some suggest that health care spending is an inefficient way to improve population health, pointing to research on the social determinants of health and their role in preventing poor health outcomes. International research shows that increased spending on social services can improve population health, but with Canada’s public health care system it’s unclear whether that holds here. We study government spending and health outcomes in Canadian provinces using 31 years of data. We wanted to know the influence of social spending on health outcomes like potentially avoidable mortality, infant mortality, and life expectancy. We find that social spending, as a fraction of health care spending, is associated with small improvements in potentially avoidable mortality and life expectancy. That means that relatively small increases in social spending, and corresponding decreases in health spending, could potentially improve population health with no change to overall provincial budgets. To draw this conclusion we considered other factors that might impact population health outcomes, like provincial gross domestic product, unemployment, population, and income inequality (among others).

column5: Neuroendocrine tumors: principles of diagnosis and management
column37: Patients most commonly present with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., cough, abdominal pain or bloating)
column39: Cancer (neuroendocrine tumour), endocrinology, oncology
column49:
Neuroendocrine tumors, formerly called carcinoid tumors, are a unique group of cancers which arise from neuroendocrine cells.  Neuroendocrine tumors can occur almost anywhere in the body, but are most commonly found in the lung, small bowel and pancreas. These tumors are best known for their ability to produce hormones, such as serotonin, which can result in a constellation of symptoms called the carcinoid syndrome.  The carcinoid syndrome is characterized by symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea, wheezing and damage to heart valves. While neuroendocrine tumors are classically thought of as slow growing cancers associated with long life-expectancies, they also have the potential to be very aggressive and can be associated with survival measured in months. 

Recent research has shown that their incidence of neuroendocrine tumors has markedly risen in Canada over the past 15 years. Along with the rise in the incidence of neuroendocrine tumors, there has been a steady increase in the amount and quality of research to determine the best diagnostic and treatment options for neuroendocrine tumors. 

This review summarizes the classification, presentation and initial diagnostic workup of neuroendocrine tumors with the aim of helping generalists facilitate timely diagnosis and referral. This review also highlights the expanding therapeutic treatment options that allow many patients with neuroendocrine tumors, even those with metastatic disease, to enjoy long periods of well-controlled symptoms and an excellent quality of life.

column5: Primary aldosteronism: a common cause of resistant hypertension
column37: Primary aldosteronism is quite common in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension; timely treatment will improve outcomes.
column39: hypertension, drugs for hypertension, cardiovascular medicine, endocrinology, metabolism
column49: Primary Aldosteronism (PA) is a disease of the hormone-producing adrenal glands in which there is excessive production of a hormone called aldosterone.  The high levels of this hormone lead to high blood pressure that may be difficult to control with medications; in its most advanced phase, it may also cause low potassium levels in the blood.  According to the latest set of studies, this condition may be responsible for between 3 to 10% of the patients with high blood pressure seen in "routine" cases and between 10 to 20% of people whose high blood pressue is considered "treatment resistant".  Compared to other forms of high blood pressure, PA appears to pose especially high risks for heart disease and stroke complications in those who are affected by the condition.  Over the past 20 years, many studies from around the world have confirmed that this is not a rare disease and there are specific treatment options including aldosterone-blocking drugs or surgical removal of the adrenal glands which may be highly effective to control or even cure the disease.  With the high number of people in Canada affected by high blood pressure, this naturally means that there are potentially a large number of patients with undiagnosed PA as well.  The authors call for increased awareness of PA among primary care providers and encourage the more frequent use of a blood test called the Aldosterone-Renin-Ratio in order to better detect affected patients who have the most to benefit from such specific treatments.

column5: Multicentre prospective validation and refinement of a clinical decision rule for the use of computed tomography in children with minor head injury in the emergency department
column36: CT in children with minor head injury
column37: The CATCH2 rule is sensitive for identifying children requiring neurosurgical intervention in the emergency department.
column39: Pediatric emergency medicine, head injury, computed tomography
column49: Head trauma is common in children and, though usually benign, it may result in rapid deterioration due to bleeding inside the head. Early detection of bleeding by CT scan is critical to good outcomes, however, CT scans should be used judiciously as they deliver radiation to the brain. Currently, there is uncertainty around which children who are symptomatic after a minor head injury need to undergo computed tomography (CT). We previously developed a decision rule comprised of seven clinical features (the CATCH rule) that predicted with high sensitivity those children requiring neurosurgical intervention and those with trauma to the brain seen on CT scan. In this study we tested this rule in a further 4060 children with blunt head trauma presenting to nine pediatric emergency departments across Canada. We found that the seven-item rule was very good but not 100% sensitive in identifying children with neurosurgical intervention. Through further analysis we refined the rule to an eight-variable rule (the CATCH2 rule) that was 100% sensitive for detecting children requiring neurosurgical intervention and 99% sensitive in detecting children with any brain trauma on CT. The next step is to further test the rule in an implementation study that assesses the clinical impact of the rule on a new set of patients. This rule will assist physicians in making decisions regarding immediate CT imaging, prompt referral to a centre with CT scanning availability or need for continued close observation in the emergency department.

column5: Evolving Epidemiology of C. difficile Infection in Canadian Hospitals during a Post-Epidemic period (2009-2015)
column36: Clostridium difficile infection in Canadian hospitals
column37: Rates of C. difficile infection have decreased across Canada (2009–2015), but the pathogenic NAP1 strain continues to predominate.
column39: infectious diseases
column49: Clostridium difficile infections (CDI) in healthcare facilities are an important patient safety issue. Major outbreaks occurred in numerous Canadian provinces in the early 2000s. This national multicentre study describes the evolution of healthcare-associated CDI in Canada over a seven-year period (2009-2015) in a network of 64 acute care hospitals that participated in the Canadian Nosocomial Infection Surveillance Program (CNISP). Over that period of time, there was a 27% reduction in the rate of CDI across Canada and significant changes in C. difficile strains circulating in hospitals. CDI caused by the NAP1 strain, previously implicated in many of the most significant outbreaks, was associated with higher mortality. While the NAP1 strain remains the dominant strain, it has become much less common and is being replaced by other strains. The authors note that for every 10% change in the proportion of the NAP1 strain among all strains at any individual hospital, the institutional rate of CDI acquired by patients changed by 3.3%.

column5: A 44-year-old man with acute asymmetric polyarthritis and fever
column37: Yu and colleagues outline how they discovered the unusual cause of this man’s polyarthritis and fever
column39: fever, rat-bite fever, laboratory testing
column49:
A 44-year-old man develops sudden swelling and pain in several joints. He also feels unwell from a fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle aches, and fatigue. His physician finds multiple inflamed joints and considers a broad list of causes. Some of these causes will resolve on their own with time, while other causes such as infections can be more serious and need immediate attention. Inflamed, swollen joints should be rapidly tested for infection by taking a sample of the joint fluid with a needle.
The patient’s tests show bacteria in the fluid, meaning he has a joint infection. Although joint infections in general are not rare, this type of bacteria found is unusual because it comes from rats. The patient later says he has frequent contact with rats that he feeds to pet snakes. This disease is sometimes called “rat-bite fever”, which is misleading because people can become infected without being bitten. Patients usually do well with antibiotic treatment.
The bacteria in “rat-bite fever” do not necessarily enter joints to cause infection there, but inflammation occurs because of an over-activated immune system. If the bacteria do enter and infect the joints, then patients benefit from more aggressive therapy with antibiotics given intravenously, and possibly even surgery.
This case shows the importance for physicians to consider a wide range of causes when dealing with multiple inflamed joints. When suspecting an infection, physicians should aggressively test the joints, treat patients with antibiotics, and be aware of “rat-bite fever” as a rare but important cause.

column5: Saving faces
column37: Society has come to accept that life without a face is like a sort of death.
column39: transplantation, humanities, antirejection drugs, social death, hisotry of medicine
column49: Following the first successful hand transplant in 1998, doctors were confident that they could transplant faces.  But it took another seven years for the first face transplant to even be attempted.  In this essay, I explain the gap between technical capability and execution.  While there were robust objections to the surgery based on the risks posed by the anti-rejection medication, the major barriers were social, having to do with the special status of the face as an index to identity, and conceptual, having to do with resistance to understanding facelessness and social death as a legitimate health risk. One of the unsettling – and fundamentally important – things about face transplant surgery is that it insists on an expanded definition of what constitutes health and wellness, and what can be done to achieve it.  At the same time, we need to examine biases against people with facial disfigurement that are so significant they actually create risks and challenges akin to death.  Rather than developing new ways of encountering others that looks beyond appearance, instead we rely on surgical procedures to make it easier to look at people face-to-face.  What it would be like to look at people face-to-faceless?  Face transplant surgery is one alternative to social death.  Surely there are others.

column5: Secrets in fingerprints: clinical ambitions and uncertainties in the history of dermatoglyphics
column12: To Duty Edit for pull quote Apr. 27
column37: This article traces clinical ambitions and uncertainty in the once-priomising field of dermatoglyphics.
column39: Down syndrome, fingerprints, dermatoglyphics, anthropology, forensic medicine, history of medicine
column49: This article examines the 20th-century history of dermatoglyphics, a scientific discipline devoted to the study of the ridged skin on palms and fingers that had connections with fields including physical anthropology, human genetics, forensic medicine, and medical genetics. This article examines one application of dermatoglyphic knowledge: the development of techniques to diagnose Down syndrome. The ambitious idea that dermatoglyphics could reveal the "secrets" of this and other congenital conditions propelled research in the field and encouraged connections among researchers and clinicians. It also eventually revealed the discipline's limitations, a point that would only become clearer amid the late 20th-century shifts in medical genetics that have made chromosomes and, ultimately, DNA the most important objects of investigation.

column5: Lyme carditis and atrioventricular block
column37: Nearly one in 10 patients with Lyme disease will develop atrioventricular block from Lyme carditis
column39: lyme diseases, ticks, insects, cardiovascular
column49: Carditis in Lyme disease occurs in younger patients and involves the conduction system. It can progress quickly to hemodynamically unstable atrioventricular block. Prompt antibiotics treatment in this reversible process may avoid the need for permanent pacemaker implantation.

column5: Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus
column37: Consider a painful vesicular rash in the V1 dermatome to be herpes zoster ophthalmicus until proven otherwise.
column39: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus, infectious disease, ophthalmology
column49: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus can have serious ocular and systemic sequelae. Patients with ocular symptoms such as decreased vision, red or painful eyes, or other high risk features should be urgently assessed by an ophthalmologist.

column5: It was never about The Cancer it was about Me
column49: My poem is about the prevalence of depression and mental illness in the medical field, drawn from my own experience and the experiences of others. I intentionally wanted to mislead the reader—at least on their first pass through—about the true diagnosis of the subject. I want the poem to probe the reader’s perceptions about mental illness: once the reader discovers that the true diagnosis is mental illness rather than cancer, does it change your appreciation for the severity of the problem? Does it make you feel less concerned with the subject’s affliction or attitudes? Does it feel disrespectful to cancer patients? Most of all: what causes us to feel this way? For an institution that prides itself for taking care of patients, we don’t always take the best care of ourselves. Worse, we encourage the same bad habits to manifest in others. The substance use, the signs of physical and mental strain, we all know it’s there and yet it’s so hard to combat. The culture of medicine itself disables us: the idea that admitting our humanity makes us weak, the length and depth of training required, the perpetual stress of fighting a medical system to give our patients what we know they need. You have all been medical students and interns. You’ve been here. Talk about your struggle. Advocate for better practices in medical education. Not just because you want a healthy doctor to take your place, but because we deserve better.

column5: YOUSEF’S STORY
column48: chemical warfare, mustard gas, weapons of mass destruction, Mosul bombing, Iraq, ISIS, ISIL, terrorism, crimes against humanity
column49: This is the story of a child I met in Iraq while serving as a humanitarian physician. His name is Yousef. He suffers from terrible disfigurement as a result of a chemical mortar that was dropped in Mosul in 2015. A sulphur mustard gas explosion was the culprit and he continues to endure significant keloid scarring to his head and neck, which of course now produces more emotional pain than other forms. He is eleven and gets teased by other children because of the way he looks. He has attempted suicide three times. And for now, he has been rescued by family three times. I learned about Yousef my first days in mission and quite honestly the story gutted me. I told my colleague immediately that “this story needs to be heard”. Its audience needs to know that these deplorable acts are not that uncommon. This is a crime of humanity and in my opinion, it is being allowed by the global community. So, the question then becomes, why?

column5: Alzheimer's Disease: The Waiting Room
Bullous cutaneous larva migrans: a diagnostic success of teledermatology
Monilethrix
column49: The term monilethrix derives from both the Latin monile (necklace) and the Greek thrix (hair). It is an autosomal dominant disorder that has been associated with mutations in type II hair keratin genes. The patient's hair  breaks easily, which usually occurs at the top of the head, nape and occipital areas. Trichoscopy can aid the diagnosis of monilethrix. Trichoscopy shows a beaded appearance due to be regular constrictions of the shaft, which is a simple, rapid, and non-invasive examination.

column5: Hepatic Sarcoidosis
column49: Hepatic sarcoidosis is one of the extra-pulmonary manifestations of sarcoidosis. 18F-FDG PET/CT is widely accepted for use in determining active sarcoid lesions. 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging can be useful for identifying hepatic sarcoidosis.

column5: Hemolytic anemia as a presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency
column49: The presentation of patients with vitamin B12 deficiency can be quite diverse, with up to 10% of patients presenting with life threatening conditions. Patients presenting with evidence of hemolysis should be carefully evaluated for the presence of vitamin B12 deficiency.

column5: Associations between rates of operative vaginal delivery and frequency of obstetric and birth trauma
column49: Rates of obstetric and severe birth trauma have increased among forceps and vacuum deliveries in Canada despite an overall decline in the frequency of these deliveries. Recommendations to increase such deliveries will likely result in substantially higher rates of obstetric anal sphincter injury among mothers.

column5: Absolute 10 year risk of dementia by age, gender and APOE genotype: a population-based cohort study
Development and validation of a cardiovascular disease risk prediction model using population health surveys: the Cardiovascular Disease Population Risk Tool (CVDPoRT)
The Relationship between Putatively Harmful and Protective Factors in Media Reports and Suicide Deaths
column49: Previous research has repeatedly shown that exposure to media reporting on suicide can lead to contagion of suicide.  In some circumstances it may also lead to help seeking behavior.  There is limited evidence for which specific characteristics of media reports mediate these phenomena and there is little Canadian research on the topic.  This study examined the relationship between potentially harmful and helpful elements of print and online media reports about suicide in 13 major publications in the Toronto media market and suicide deaths in Toronto (2011-2014).  Specifically, it assessed for a link between specific types of reporting and suicide deaths within the 7 days after publication.  It found that from 2011-2014, there were 6,367 articles with suicide as the major focus.  There were 947 suicide deaths in Toronto over the same period.  Elements most strongly, independently associated with increased suicides were a statement that suicide is inevitable, articles about asphyxia other than by hanging or car exhaust, about suicide by jumping from a building, about suicide pacts and that included the suicide method in the headline.  Elements most strongly, independently associated with decreased suicides were negative judgments about the deceased within the article, articles about railway and cutting/stabbing deaths, and about murder-suicide.  This large study identified significant associations between several specific elements of media reports and suicide deaths.  It suggests that reporting on suicide can have a meaningful impact on suicide deaths and that journalists and media outlets/organizations should carefully consider the specific content of reports prior to publication.

column5: 42. Sleeping on a firm mattress is effective in the treatment of low back pain
43. Peer support improves outcomes for patients with chronic diseases
44. Patients with a first unprovoked deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolus, should be routinely tested for Factor V Leiden and prothrombin gene mutations
45. For antibiotic-resistant cases of Helicobacter pylori, bismuth-containing quadruple therapy is more effective than standard triple therapies
46. It is unknown whether probiotics can help prevent Clostridium difficile infection in people who use proton pump inhibitors
47. For patients who are acutely agitated in the emergency department or mental health unit, there is little evidence to guide drug treatment
48. For relief of travellers' diarrhea, treatment with bismuth subsalicylate taken orally is as effective and safe as treatment with loperamide
49. Using point-of-care troponin testing in the emergency department, for patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome, improves patient outcomes like mortality and quality of life
50. For the treatment of toenail fungal nail infections, the topical agent efinaconazole seems to be as effective as oral antifungal agents
51. Using capnography to monitor patients undergoing procedural sedation enables better detection of respiratory problems
52: In outpatients discharged after stroke or TIA, monitoring for atrial fibrillation for more than 24 hours substantially increases the diagnostic yield over monitoring for less than 24 hours.

column5: 53: Nonsurgical medical treatment is more effective than bariatric surgery for sustained (five-year) weight loss in obese patients with type 2 diabetes
54. A higher dose of acetaminophen (1000 mg) for post-surgical pain relief after surgery is associated with a higher risk of adverse events than a lower dose (650 mg).
55. In treating anemia, oral preparations of iron complex supplements are more effective than those of other iron supplements
56. In emergency departments, digital temporal artery thermometers are reliable for detecting fever in all pediatric patients.
57. Testing for sexually transmitted infections in women using self-collected samples is as effective as testing using clinician-collected samples
58. Available evidence supports giving vitamin D supplements to residents of long-term care facilities for the prevention of falls
59. Much evidence supports use of high-dose psychostimulants for symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in adolescents and adults
60. Because newer-generation wireless devices emit less electromagnetic radiation, their use does not need to be restricted in health care settings
61. Buprenorphine/naloxone is more effective than methadone for maintaining abstinence from opioid use
62. To quit smoking, nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is the most effective drug aid
63 There is good evidence that home use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation  effectively reduces chronic pain
64. There is evidence to support using topical estrogen for prevention of urinary tract infection in postmenopausal women who have previously had these infections.
65. Urgent fecal occult blood testing in patients with suspected gastrointestinal bleeding leads to improved health outcomes.
66. Patients with end-stage kidney disease who need dialysis prefer treatment in a clinical setting with the assistance of a health care professional
67. Dialysis provided in a clinical setting offers improved clinical health benefits compared to self-care, home-based treatment
68. Topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been proven to be as effective as opioids in treating acute musculoskeletal pain
69. At present, it is not known if vaccinating males against the human papillomavirus (HPV) is clinically effective or cost-effective
70. Adult patients with mild obstructive sleep apnea should be treated with continuous positive airway pressure
71. Moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea in adults can be treated effectively with either continuous positive airway pressure or oral appliances
72. There are no serious side effects to using fluoroquinolones (antibiotics)
